fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a ring R, a \mathbb {Z}-grading on R is the same as a \mathbf {G}_{m}-action on \operatorname {Spec} R, where \mathbf {G}_{m} is the scheme of invertible elements.

A morphism \rho : \mathbf {G}_{m} \times \operatorname {Spec} R \to \operatorname {Spec} R is given by a ring homomorphism R \to \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \otimes R \cong R[x, x^{-1}]. Composing with the identity 1 \to \mathbf {G}_{m}, we are required that R \xrightarrow { \rho } R[x, x^{-1}] \xrightarrow {x \mapsto 1} R is the identity.

We can regard R[x, x^{-1}] as generated by (n, r) \in \mathbb {Z} \times R, where the first number is the degree of x and the second number is the coefficient. So they are under the relations (n, r) + (n, r') = (n, r + r'), and (n, r) \cdot (m, r') = (n + m, r r'). \rho (r) is a sum of finitely many (n, r_n), and the identity law requires the sum of r_n is r again. This decomposes r into its components in each degree.

Next, the associativity law essentially requires that, if (n, r_n) is a summand of some \rho (r), then \rho (r_n) = (n, r_n). So this is indeed a well-defined decomposition. Furthermore, \rho being a ring homomorphism guarantees that the grading respects multiplication and addition.

We define the scheme \mathbf {G}_{m} as \operatorname {Spec} \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}]. It can be characterized by the points \hom ( \mathbf {G}_{m} , \operatorname {Spec} R) = R^ \times being the units of R. This scheme has a group structure. Since it is affine, 1 \to \mathbf {G}_{m} is given by the ring homomorphism \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \to \mathbb Z sending x to 1. The product map is given by a ring homomorphism \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \otimes \mathbb {Z}[y, y^{-1}] \to \mathbb {Z}[z, z^{-1}] (where we renamed the variables for clarity) sending x \otimes y to z. The inverse map \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \to \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] sends x to x^{-1}.

A D-graded ring is a sequence of abelian groups R_d, where d \in D are elements of a commutative monoid called the grading. We have a bilinear multiplication map R_p \otimes R_q \to R_{p+q} and a identity element 1 \in R_0 satisfying the associativity and identity laws.
Usually, the grading is one of \mathbb Z or \mathbb N. A bigraded ring is graded over D^2 instead of D, whatever the context implies the grading is.

If we regard the grading on a commutative ring R as a group action \rho : \mathbf {G}_{m} \times \operatorname {Spec} R \to \operatorname {Spec} R, quotienting with this action, i.e. taking the coequalizer of the parallel arrows \rho , \pi _2 : \mathbf {G}_{m} \times \operatorname {Spec} R \rightrightarrows \operatorname {Spec} R we get \operatorname {Proj} R, the projective spectrum of a graded ring.
